target_text: "The agile process itself is subject to continuous improvements. We use retrospectives to continuously reflect on the way we work to become better at what we do and ultimately better at delivering quality software. That’s the process."

Role.Subject: Statistics
Role.positionality: I am a software developer pursuing a bachelor’s degree in statistics, bringing computational pragmatism to economic questions. My research goal is to build reproducible, data-driven analyses that translate statistical evidence into policy-relevant economic insights. I acknowledge cultural and personal biases—favoring algorithmic efficiency, market-oriented explanations, and English-language sources—that shape what I read, model, and report. I reflect on how the question’s framing and the user’s response interact with my background to prioritize hypotheses, steer goals toward tractable problems, amplify biases, and narrow interpretations; thus I employ transparency, alternative specifications, and robustness checks to counterbalance these influences.

codebook.justification: I interpret [subject to continuous improvements] as a normative kaizen stance. My SE/HCI lens privileges iterative refinement, foregrounding culture over static methods.
Emphasizing [continuously reflect] via retrospectives signals institutionalized reflexivity. My researcher bias valorizes such meta-work as a capability-building mechanism.
The telos is [delivering quality software], framing process as instrumental to value. From a software engineering perspective, ‘quality’ is contested and socially constructed.
The closure [That’s the process.] asserts process primacy as identity. My positionality may overread process as culture, potentially downplaying product-context contingencies.
